description:
The reason that off-axis projections have slightly different orientations now is that the Camera is now default-constructed and then modified several times to be consistent with what the user asks for. Because the camera has some memory of it's previous state, this results in a different orientation than what was computed before the refactor, when the orientation was determined in one shot.

When a north_vector is not specified, the default choice is arbitrary, so the new behavior is just as valid as the old. However, this will cause old scripts to give different results than before, which is probably not desirable. This PR makes the orientation the same as it was before the refactor. 

UPDATE: I have modified the Orientation class so that the default unit vectors will match on-axis projections when the normal_vector lies along one of the coordinate axes.
title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

pullrequest.title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

content.raw:
I have tested this PR to assure that it gets the proper RHS results for on-axis and off-axis projections (as well as LHS results for VR).  This follows a similar script I cited in a similar PR with the old off-axis projection code we did several months ago ( https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-requests/1736/bugfix-change-vr-to-rhs-fix-758/diff ).  

I'm a bit confused by the results.  When I run this script on the tip of yt dev (f4b8c48fae30), I get good results.  When i run this script on the tip of this PR, I get the same results.  Not sure where things are going awry in the existing framework.

Script:

```
#!python


import yt

ds = yt.load("IsolatedGalaxy/galaxy0030/galaxy0030")
x_vector = ds.arr([1,0,0], 'code_length') # x
z_vector = ds.arr([0,0,1], 'code_length') # z

# On axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
on = yt.ProjectionPlot(ds, 'x', 'density', width=(25, 'kpc'))
on.hide_colorbar()
on.hide_axes()
on.save('on.png')

# Off axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
off = yt.OffAxisProjectionPlot(ds, x_vector, 'density', width=(25, 'kpc'),
                               north_vector=z_vector)
off.hide_colorbar()
off.hide_axes()
off.save('off.png')

# Volume rendering, camera is positioned at x unit_vector relative to focus,
# with north vec = z
x_vector = ds.arr([1,0,0], 'code_length') # x; needs redefining because changed
sc = yt.create_scene(ds, 'density')
sc.camera.set_width(ds.arr([25, 25, 25], 'kpc'))
sc.camera.set_position(sc.camera.focus + x_vector, north_vector=z_vector)
sc.camera.resolution = (800, 800)
tf = sc.get_source(0).transfer_function
tf.clear()
tf.add_layers(3, 0.01, col_bounds=[-26,-23], colormap = 'RdBu_r')
sc.render()
sc.save('vr.png', sigma_clip=4.0)
```

Images with tip of yt dev (or tip of this PR) (on.png, off.png, vr.png):

![on.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/407366238-on.png)
![off.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/1031434630-off.png)
![vr.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/482751060-vr.png)
content.html:
I have tested this PR to assure that it gets the proper RHS results for on-axis and off-axis projections (as well as LHS results for VR). This follows a similar script I cited in a similar PR with the old off-axis projection code we did several months ago ( https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-requests/1736/bugfix-change-vr-to-rhs-fix-758/diff ).

I'm a bit confused by the results. When I run this script on the tip of yt dev (f4b8c48fae30), I get good results. When i run this script on the tip of this PR, I get the same results. Not sure where things are going awry in the existing framework.

Script:

import yt

ds = yt.load("IsolatedGalaxy/galaxy0030/galaxy0030")
x_vector = ds.arr([1,0,0], 'code_length') # x
z_vector = ds.arr([0,0,1], 'code_length') # z

# On axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
on = yt.ProjectionPlot(ds, 'x', 'density', width=(25, 'kpc'))
on.hide_colorbar()
on.hide_axes()
on.save('on.png')

# Off axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
off = yt.OffAxisProjectionPlot(ds, x_vector, 'density', width=(25, 'kpc'),
                               north_vector=z_vector)
off.hide_colorbar()
off.hide_axes()
off.save('off.png')

# Volume rendering, camera is positioned at x unit_vector relative to focus,
# with north vec = z
x_vector = ds.arr([1,0,0], 'code_length') # x; needs redefining because changed
sc = yt.create_scene(ds, 'density')
sc.camera.set_width(ds.arr([25, 25, 25], 'kpc'))
sc.camera.set_position(sc.camera.focus + x_vector, north_vector=z_vector)
sc.camera.resolution = (800, 800)
tf = sc.get_source(0).transfer_function
tf.clear()
tf.add_layers(3, 0.01, col_bounds=[-26,-23], colormap = 'RdBu_r')
sc.render()
sc.save('vr.png', sigma_clip=4.0)

Images with tip of yt dev (or tip of this PR) (on.png, off.png, vr.png):

pullrequest.title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

content.raw:
I reran my test after removing the kwarg for `north_vector=z_vector` in the Off-axis projection to see the impact of not specifying a north vector.  Using yt dev tip, I get off.png as:

![off.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/1754228520-off.png)

Using this PR, I get off.png as:

![off.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/3973938208-off.png)

But shouldn't off.png be like the on.png (ie with a north vector = z, not a north vector = y)?  Or am I missing something?
content.html:
I reran my test after removing the kwarg for north_vector=z_vector in the Off-axis projection to see the impact of not specifying a north vector. Using yt dev tip, I get off.png as:

Using this PR, I get off.png as:

But shouldn't off.png be like the on.png (ie with a north vector = z, not a north vector = y)? Or am I missing something?

pullrequest.title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

content.raw:
This is how it actually it worked before the volume render refactor, too. I get the same results as the above when I run your script on the stable branch. 

In this PR, I was just trying to make the new off_axis_projection (in dev, after the VR refactor) behave like the old one. But, it may well be that the old behavior wasn't ideal, either. The options are: 

1. Make off_axis_projection behave like it always did, or 
2. Make off_axis_projection use an orientation that is consistent with on-axis projections when no north_vector is specified.

Option 2 is probably more intuitive for new users, but it also means that old scripts will give different results than under previous versions.
content.html:
This is how it actually it worked before the volume render refactor, too. I get the same results as the above when I run your script on the stable branch.

In this PR, I was just trying to make the new off_axis_projection (in dev, after the VR refactor) behave like the old one. But, it may well be that the old behavior wasn't ideal, either. The options are:

  1. Make off_axis_projection behave like it always did, or
  2. Make off_axis_projection use an orientation that is consistent with on-axis projections when no north_vector is specified.

Option 2 is probably more intuitive for new users, but it also means that old scripts will give different results than under previous versions.

pullrequest.title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

content.raw:
Thanks for the clarification there.  I could go either way on this.  I understand the desire to have backwards compatibility with old scripts using the old OAP, but I like having the OAP give you the same results as the on-axis projection when you don't specify a `north_vector`.  I'm +0.5 on changing it, but I won't hold things up if people want to just leave things as they are in the PR.

Thanks for addressing this, @atmyers !
content.html:
Thanks for the clarification there. I could go either way on this. I understand the desire to have backwards compatibility with old scripts using the old OAP, but I like having the OAP give you the same results as the on-axis projection when you don't specify a north_vector. I'm +0.5 on changing it, but I won't hold things up if people want to just leave things as they are in the PR.

Thanks for addressing this, Andrew Myers !

pullrequest.title: Making off axis projections have the same orientation vectors as before.

content.raw:
This only makes a difference for Off Axis Projections, but for a sorta complicated reason. This code is only called the first time you construct an Orientation. In the VR interface, you never do this directly. Instead, you are supposed to construct a default Camera, and then modify it through a series of calls to set_position, switch_orientation, etc. This default Camera is always at the upper right-hand corner of the domain, looking at the center. This change makes no difference in that special case - all three components of "t" are 0, regardless of the order of the cross product, so the code arbitrarily picks the first axis before and after this change. 

That said, I don't think it would be a problem if it did make a difference. All this would change it the default orientation of the north / east vectors when none is specified. Any choice should be as good as any other. This choice just happens to be the one that is consistent with on axis projections.
content.html:
This only makes a difference for Off Axis Projections, but for a sorta complicated reason. This code is only called the first time you construct an Orientation. In the VR interface, you never do this directly. Instead, you are supposed to construct a default Camera, and then modify it through a series of calls to set_position, switch_orientation, etc. This default Camera is always at the upper right-hand corner of the domain, looking at the center. This change makes no difference in that special case - all three components of "t" are 0, regardless of the order of the cross product, so the code arbitrarily picks the first axis before and after this change.

That said, I don't think it would be a problem if it did make a difference. All this would change it the default orientation of the north / east vectors when none is specified. Any choice should be as good as any other. This choice just happens to be the one that is consistent with on axis projections.
